children.name: Two decision problems for logics
Satisfiability is φ true in some model?
Model checking is φ true in some model M?
M fixed, φ input
M input, φ input
M input, φ fixed
Part 1.
Part 2.
Part 3.
M fixed φ input
First-order logic
For which structures M is the following problem decidable: Given a sentence of first-order logic φ, is φ is true in M?
two element structure fo
What can a first-order sentence say in {0,1} ?
This is enough to encode QBF (quantified Boolean formulas)
Theorem. For every finite M, its first-order theory is PSpace complete.
Hardness is already for {0,1} with equality only.
Membership is witnessed by the naive algorithm
arithmetic
Theorem. The first-order theory of (ℕ, +, ×) is undecidable.
arithmetic proof sketch
Proof sketch. We can use numbers to represent lists of numbers.
First-order logic can define operations such as head, or concatenation.
A list can represent a computation of a Turing machine.
Using the list operations, one can formalize in first-order logic the statement “there exists an accepting computation”.
In fact, undecidability holds already for ∃* formulas:
Theorem. [DPLM] Hilbert’s 10-th problem is undecidable: Input. a polynomial Question.
There is a polynonial P such that x is a prime number iff
There is a polynomial P such that
Tarski arithmetic
Theorem. [Tarski 1929] The first-order theory of (ℝ, +, ×) is decidable.
Tarski’s proof used quantifier elimination:
Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), one can compute an equivalent quantifier-free formula in (ℝ, +, ×, –, ≤, 0, 1, )
Applying the main lemma to a formula without free variables, we compute an equivalent formula like (1 – 1 = 0 ∨ 0 > 1), whose truth can be easily decided.
Example 1
This is because quantifier-free formulas are Boolean combinations of polynomial inequalities.
Hence there is no formula for “x is a natural number”.
Presburger arithmetic
Theorem. [Presburger 1929] The first-order theory of (ℕ, +) is decidable.
Main lemma. For every first-order formula φ(x1, ... xn), the defined subset of ℕⁿ is semilinear, i.e it is a finite union of linear sets:
Proof. The base case is the formula
Semilinear sets are closed under union, projection, and complementation.
projection is ∃
Consider a formula
The quantified formula
technical
We will later see an alternative decidability proof, using automata.
Second-order logic
second order logic
In second-order logic, we can write formulas like:
Theorem. For every structure M: 1. if M is finite, then its second-order theory is PSpace complete. 2. if M is infinite, then its second-order theory is undecidable.
Proof. 1. PSpace hardness is inherited from first-order logic, PSpace membership uses the naive algorithm.
2. Undecidability is witnessed by formulas of the form:
Monadic second-order logic
monadic second order logic
Example. The MSO theory of (ℕ, =) is decidable. Every formula is equivalent to a quantifier-free formula using X(x), |X| = n and |ℕ - X| = n.
Question. [Tarski] Is the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) decidable?
Robinson’s paper shows that the MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤, 2x) is undecidable.
The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable
The MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable
weak mso
Weak MSO has the same syntax as MSO, but set quantification is restricted to finite sets.
∃X ∀x x ∈ X
Theorem. [BEEVT] The weak MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.
weak mso automata
Consider a formula φ(x, Y, Z ) of weak MSO. How do we represent the semantics of φ, which is a set of triples (number, finite set of numbers, finite set of numbers)?
A quantifier-free formula?
A semilinear set?
An automaton!
triples of sets as finite words
Lemma. For every formula of weak MSO, one can compute a finite automaton that recognizes the corresponding set of words
weak mso automata proof
Proof. Induction on formula size.
For the atomic formulas
For ∨ and ¬, we use closure of regular languages under union and complementation.
For ∃, we use closure of regular languages under projection:
If L ⊆ (Σ × Γ)* is regular, then so is its projection π(L) ⊆ Σ*.
deterministic automata
nondeterministic automata, or regular expressions
If the formula alternates n times between complementation and projection, then determinization is applied n times, resulting in an n-fold exponential automaton.
mso history
Trakhtenbrot 1958
image 2
Büchi and Elgot 1958
Group 14
Group 13
Ehrenfeucht and Vaught ≤ 1958
Ehrenfeucht and Vaught
For a description of this history, see W. Thomas, SIGLOG 2019
We can use ordinals to represents numbers and finite sets of numbers
ω5 represents the number 5
ω5 + ω2 + 1 represents the set {0, 2, 5}
not the same as 1 + ω2 + ω5 = ω5
Under this representation, membership x ∈ X and order can be defined in first-order logic using ordinal addition α + β
Only ordinals α < ω are needed, and (ω , <, +) has decidable first-order theory [Ehrenfeucht 1957 +]
Group 6
Automatic Presburger
Represent a number as a finite set, namely its binary expansion
Under this representation, there is a WMSO formula for x + y = z
Corollary For every formula φ(x1, ... xn) of Presburger arithmetic, the corresponding n-ary relation on binary expansions is definable in WMSO (equivalently, can be recognized by a finite automaton).
The corollary would still be true if we added “x is a power of 2”
or “x is the smallest power of 2 that divides both y and z”
(ℤ, +) is an example of an automatic group [Thurston, Epstein, ... 1980’s], or more generally an automatic structure [Nerode, Khoussainov 1994]
Büchi mso
Theorem. [Büchi 1962] The MSO theory of (ℕ, ≤) is decidable.
The proof is the same as for weak MSO, except that now we need to generalize automata from finite word to infinite words.
Büchi automata
Nondeterministic Büchi automata
Syntax: same as for nondeterministic finite automata.
Semantics: an ω-word is accepted if an accepting state appears ∞ often
When viewed an automaton on finite words, the language is {a, b}*
When viewed a Büchi automaton, the language is {a, b}*a
Büchi automata do not determinize, but they are still closed under: 1. union and intersection 2. projection 3. complementation
Büchi’s proof for item 3 used the Ramsey theorem
For more on Büchi automata, see Orna’s talk
The MSO theory of ({0,1}*, ≤) is decidable
Rabin mso
Theorem. [Rabin 1969] The MSO theory of ({0,1}*, ≤) is decidable.
Rabin tree
This is the tree of bit-strings, ordered by the prefix relation.
A modern proof:
nondeterministic parity tree automata
parity tree automata
Tree automata
A transition in a word automaton looks like this:
A transition in a tree automaton looks like this:
Parity condition
Instead of an accepting subset F ⊆ Q, there is parity ranking function Q → {0, 1, ...}
A run is accepting if for every branch in the tree, the rank seen infinitely often is even.
closed under: union, intersection and projection
alternating parity tree automata
closed under: union, intersection and complementation
special case
uses: 1. determinization for ω-automata 2. finite memory strategies for games
For more on tree automata, see Orna’s talk
The MSO theory of (ℝ, ≤) is undecidable
Shelah mso
(ℝ, ≤) and (ℚ, ≤) have the same first-order theories, but different MSO theories.
because both are dense linear orders without endpoints
“every set has a least upper bound”
Theorem. [Shelah 1975] The MSO theory of (ℝ, ≤) is decidable (assuming CH).
A difficult proof, which manages to represent arithmetic on integers using order in the real numbers
Counterpoint 1. Every MSO formula φ(x) is equivalent to either “true” or “false”.
Because every x, x’ ∈ ℝ can be mapped to each other using an order-preserving bijection of (ℝ, ≤)
Counterpoint 2. The MSO theory of (ℚ, ≤) is decidable.
Q theory
ε
This is a countable dense linear order without endpoints, and hence it is isomorphic to (ℚ, ≤).
